unnormalised: Someone asked me why Indian Standard Time (IST) is +5:30 GMT. Why not just +5 or +6? Well, imagine telling your boss in Mumbai that the meeting with the London team is at 2:30 PM IST when it's *actually* at 10:00 AM GMT. Total chaos, right? We’d have to prepone *everything* just to keep everyone on the same page. Plus, think of all the confusion during cricket matches! 'India needs 36 runs in 3 overs'. Except wait, what 'overs' are *we* talking about?
normalised: Someone asked me why Indian Standard Time (I-S-T) is plus five thirty G-M-T. Why not just plus five or plus six? Well, imagine telling your boss in Mumbai that the meeting with the London team is at two thirty P-M I-S-T when it's actually at ten zero zero A-M G-M-T. Total chaos, right? We’d have to prepone everything just to keep everyone on the same page. Plus, think of all the confusion during cricket matches! 'India needs thirty six runs in three overs'. Except wait, what 'overs' are we talking about?

unnormalised: Seriously though, there's a historical reason! Back in the day (like, pre-independence), India had multiple local time zones! Can you imagine the nightmare for train schedules? Someone in Kolkata would arrive 30 minutes before they left! The British finally standardized it to a time based on 82.5° East longitude. That's where the +5:30 from GMT comes from. So next time you're scheduling a call at 7:00 PM EST, remember it's 4:30 AM IST. Don't blame *us* for the odd number! Blame the prime meridian!

unnormalised: And hey, that extra 30 minutes? It's what makes us uniquely Indian. We can't just be like everyone else with their neat, round hour offsets. No sir! We need that extra half hour to finish our chai and samosas before that 11:00 AM meeting! And to argue with our watchmen, who always seem to be 5 mins slow...or maybe that's just me.
